content: So I think we should discuss the future of this group at some point. I'm taking a hard look at my own time/resources and trying to focus and pare back where it makes sense, and I know a lot of us who were involved are going through various transitions right now. There's also the ongoing work to create a foundation which will consume time and energy.

I guess I'm wondering if it makes sense to suspend the group meetings (and maybe group) for a bit, and consider revisiting? On the other hand, I think a lot of the questions we've been talking about (domain working groups, rfcs, etc) are still quite relevant.
Similarly I still feel like the compiler team could use help in writing down and formulating our processes etc
in short I still think there's work to do :)
but I am rethinking my own commitments and trying to make sure they are realistic

Can some of the work be subsumed into other activities/groups? (I don't have any specific ideas for how this would work.) Would it help for me to take a more active role and spend more time on this group's projects?

Yeah I was going to discuss this next week. With the shortage of time I think we should focus on trying to get just a single task completed for the end of the year. I have an idea of what that could be which I think ties together our previous work. Basically inspired by the django governance rfc, I would love if we could have a similar document that provides a similar high level overview of the governance of the project.

I don't know if one task requires regular meetings though. It seems like something that can handled mostly async.
That does inspirational, though I think it's no small task

It is possible that we could find a way to operate that would help, not sure, it is also possible that other folks might like to get involved (e.g., @ag_dubs, though she's not presently subscribed to this stream) and that might increase overall bandwidth.
I think a key thing would be "how is that document made" -- we've talked about the idea of going in to work with teams to get the work done
(and in that sense I personally might enjoy participating not as a member of gov wg but as a rep of compiler or lang or something)

Yeah, thinking on this more I think there's a blocker to writing that document which is more of the teams having charters so their roles are clear and can be then be included as a summary in a higher level document. There's been quite a bit of progress on the libs team towards this, so maybe we should start to approach more teams about helping to create a charter?

So far I‚Äôve found the ‚Äúgeneral compass direction‚Äù kind of support from the group in what we should be trying to establish and what tools/approaches work for other teams to be really helpful. Maybe capturing some of that in docs would be a low-bandwidth way to support other teams?
@XAMPPRocky that was our current plan, iirc, we just haven't made a lot of progress on it for other teams -- but starting with libs seems good.
I think @Josh Triplett and I would be enthusiastic to do the work from lang
it's also true that the last like 3 weeks have been... a bit distracting :)
Indeed. Might I suggest a hiatus, and we can re-evaluate in two months?
Happy to support the creation of the document in any way that is practicable. Indeed, recent events have been quite distracting.
I think that taking a hiatus is a good idea and re-evaluating
we could just say 1 month
I do feel like a lot more will be clearer then
no need to stop pursuing the work on libs charter etc in the meantime
and I think we could do async work e.g. on a lang charter, @Josh Triplett
though we may just not have time for that, no pressure...plenty to do
:+1:

Hi, some sad news: My new job is very demanding and it is clear I won't be able to contribute to the development of the very good RFC recently posted or other efforts for some time, although I can help review papers for RustConf next year as I'll have had some time to adapt by then . . . I'll remove myself from the group list on Github. Someday I hope to find another way to help.
